p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Thirteenth Biennial Report OF THE Commandant OP THE Soldiers' and Sailors' Home MILFORD, NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium Ending November 30, 1918

254 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' HOME, MILFORD. NEBRASKA OFFICERS OF THE HOME W. N. Hexsi.ky Commandant W. D. Rowdkn Adjutant H. J. Wertm.w Surgeon Dora Bchvltz Matron R. H. Biett<;e\ha< h ngineer

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 255 SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' HOME, MILFORD, NEBRASKA To his Excellency, Honorable Keith Xerille, Governor, ami to the Honorable Members of tin- Board of ('oiiuiiis- wisxioncrx of State Institution*, Henry limits. Silas A. Holcomb, ami Eugene 0. Mayfield. Gentlemen : I have the honor to submit this, the thirteenth biennial report of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Home, Milford, Nebraska. Since taking charge, May 15th, 1918, as superintendent of the institution a few very urgent and necessary improve - ments have been made. About 400 feet of twenty year old defective water main, extending from the stand-pipe to the reservoir at Coon Creek, has been replaced by a new 4 inch water main, thus affording an abundant supply of fresh water for all purposes, as well as greater fire protection, not including however water for drinking and cooking purposes, which is supplied from a separate well. Eight hundred forty square feet of cement walk and flooring have been built and approximately 1200 feet of cinder walk extending from the "Home" grounds en - trance to the village limits of Milford, have been rebuilt and improved, making pedestrian travel between the home and the village more pleasant and free from mud and dampness. Owing to the June, 1918, hot blast, followed by continued dry weather through the past cropping season, no garden or other products were grown, except about 100 bushels of com. AH refuse and slops from the kitchens and tables, instead of a loss have been turned to clear profit through feeding same to the hogs. The pump house adjoining the engine room and the reservoir have been repaired by building them higher and adding new roofing. Other minor improvements have also been made. The health of the membership has maintained an excep-

256 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF tionally high mark during the past six months, with not a single pronounced case of the influenza. The members have earned highest praise from the pub - lic and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions for their ready and cheerful obedience to all rules adopted by the Board and enforced by the executive officers of the institution. This is evidenced by the fact that there has not been a dismissal for cause during the six months of my superintendence. In concluding this brief summary, as a preface to the accompanying statistical biennial report of this institution, I cannot refrain from expressing my grateful acknowledg - ment to the individual members of the Board and to my co - executive officers for the courteous and fair treatment re - ceived at their hands during my incumbency. I also desire to thank the Woman's Relief Corps of the state for their very liberal donation to the "Home" of the rare and delicious delicacies on Thanksgiving day. I have the honor to be, Yours very respectfully Commandant. Milford. Nebraska, November 30, 1918. W. N. Hensley.
